What does HOK activity look like?

HOK activity is going to be more akin to a threat actor has gained remote access to a command shell via C2, compromised a mailbox, etc. So think about what a threat actor is going to start doing once a device is compromised and running malware that gives access to him:Enumeration of assets, ports, services, updates etc; reconnaissance of your network, lateral movement like RDP, WMI etc; executing PowerShell commands to pull more payloads down or to deploy malware to other endpoints; privilege escalation, dumping lsass, running mimikatz or other ways of getting higher level credentials, configuring outlook rules to hide activities, logging into multiple assets that are unexpected, disabling MFA, etc.This is a great resource to see the step by step that a threat actor would perform once they gained shell or remote access to a host. https://thedfirreport.com/Most alerts are going to be normal behavior that should be reviewed, but is likely an IT person or reasonable behavior. When it is a threat actor with HOK you will typically recognize it as not normal, and it should be escalated to IR. How often do you see a doctor or accountant or customer service running power shell download cradles with obfuscation, or enumerating all the domain admins/domain controllers in your environment? Likely never, so when you see something like that, it is a massive red alert.
I’ve only been in the SOC for half a year and worked with threat hunters, but I’d say it’s an active threat (HOK) vs something that has already happened (High alert)

Have I misunderstood DMARC this whole time?

SPF verifies the source of the mail is authorised for the domain.DKIM cryptographically signs the message, and the signature is verified with the public key published in DNSDMARC verifies whether SPF and DKIM pass or fail and the alignment of the domain in the FROM: header with the envelope/return-path (SPF) or DKIM signature. Strict alignment means the entire FQDN must match, relaxed means the domain must match.If either SPF or DMARC pass and are aligned, then the DMARC passes and should be accepted. If both fail or are not aligned, DMARC fails and the recipient should handle the message as specified in the policy, though this may be overridden.In the case of third parties sending mail on your behalf, you should have a CNAME record set up to the relevent TXT record of the service provider containing the DKIM public key, so the domain can align.Assuming your SPF record is well managed and regularly audited, and DKIM records are set up properly, there should be no illigitimate mail passing on DMARC unless a users account (or service provider) is compromised.All of these mechanisms protect your own domains from abuse. They do not necessarily mean that inbound mail is legitimate and/or trustworthy.

DMARC is based on the RFC5322.From address.If you have a DMARC policy for the domain used in the RFC5322.From, it will protect unauthenticated/unaligned emails sent using your domain in that same header.SPF and DKIM are authentication mechanisms against which alignment is checked for DMARC.

So if a bad actor was only header FROM spoofing, assuming the envelope from is legit and configured, that emails could come in as passing DMARCDMARC is the reporting mechanism. Your DMARC policy tells email relays what to do with emails that do not conform. You also need to look a bit more into "passing DMARC" as a phishing email can pass all DMARC checks. You can't really stop an email from passing DMARC if the attackers are using a domain they control.If your SPF record is correctly set (e.g., not overly broad, controlled sources(, an attacker spoofing your domain will be flagged.

Just heard that you can feed your physical security logs into the SIEM?

ID card is tied to a person, Person is tied to a AD account. Voila! Physical/digital correlation!You can now see someone enter the building, and then log in on their desktop.Someone swipe OUT of the building for lunch THEN log in to their desktop? Compromised account from internal source (fraud?).2am login? That's weird. But look! They swiped in 10 minutes before! Not a compromised account but a keen worker!Lots of use cases depending on the environment.

It is a niche use case, but can be useful for access logging, auditing, or even alerting when users are entering a restricted area. Useful for impossible travel or location based alerting too - How did User A swipe in if they also established a VPN connection? Why did User B log on to an office workstation if there’s no record of physical entry today. Might even be for fire drill reporting - you have an up to date list of everyone who entered the building.Once had a use case for monitoring employee entry times and comparing their working hours but HR typically nixes that.
You can feed whatever logs you want into a SIEM. And depending on the information available, you can easily configure alerts surrounding physical access using your SIEM.
Why not? Perfect use case to monitor who/when someone badged in/out.

We feed it our badge logs mostly for impossible travel detections, forensic situations, and anomaly detection. It's not 100% necessary for the cyber security team to have those logs, but since we have the big log aggregator and a bunch of smart people, we get to have them lol.

We considered it for insider threat cases like people entering offices at odd times coupled with other UBA signals. Kinda fell off the radar with Covid and physical office access not being a thing due to WFH for the majority of people.

Absolutely. Our physical access control logs are ingested and used in correlation searches and support investigations. It also helps for separate physical security solutions at different sites where it can alert not only physically impossible virtual logins, but for example, also identify if somebody is breaking the laws of physics (as in, they're not in two places at once).

I've seen it done for a well-known government body who were super fixated with the bottom of the stack; they had super robust controls around datacentre access &c. Further up the stack was neglected, lots of risks (for instance they didn't have VPNs so they wanted a cable duct filled with concrete to mitigate the risk of somebody on the campus physically tapping into a cable between buildings, like a 1970s spy movie). Anyway, the service owner wanted extra detective controls so they'd know which engineer went into which hall of the DC at what time.They use the data to find "gaps" in some of their procedural controls around access (by trusted engineers who had a change request &c); maybe they found some more direct security benefits, perhaps around monitoring remote workers, but from my perspective they wanted the logs and they got the logs and I got paid. :-)Also as an interim thing when a company split, they were untangling their IT as well as their physical sites simultaneously and wanted to be able to look for patterns of entry that didn't match our assumptions. Maybe it identified some cleaners or site-maintenance people &c.​Thought the use case for SIEM was to monitor network infrastructureA SIEM can monitor all kinds of other stuff! Especially on the server side.

As long as the system generates useable logging. This was the whole fusion concept and a big pitch between ASIS and ISC2 a decade ago.Real problem (my personal observation), organizational silos around physical security and infosec and challenges giving up or sharing their empires created challenges.Useful applications exist for sure.These days I see a lot of folks asking to correlate acms data with IP/login information to say “person X at site Y is physically present at the location from which the user logon took place”; But not for security…more for monitoring who’s actually “Getting back in the office so we can all be together again”.

A good SIEM can take nearly any log and manipulate it as you please. The only two real limitations are that the log source must have a standard format that makes sense and that you have the ability to write a parser if the vendor doesn't already provide one.Airports can have a mixture of IT, OT, and other such that SIEMs can ingest and take action on.The biggest challenge here is that physical security often is its own vertical. But, imagine if a SOC gets an alert that someone has opened a door at 2am on a Sunday that has never been opened at 2am on a Sunday. They can contact physical security and have them investigate.Similarly, if your logs capture when someone badges in, it may catch a duplicated badge doing an "impossible badge-in" where they badge in the East Coast location and within an hour badge in at the West Coast location.Just because it isn't common, doesn't mean it shouldn't be happened.

You can but it’s not much good without detection rules. I doubt the SIEM vendor would have a prebuilt parser so you’d likely need to set that up first and then made detection rules for the log source.

Most SIEMs can take in both structured and unstructured data. The problem is always what the source can do. Can it actually feed its logs in realtime or does it only export logs to a file that has to be read in.

Big Bosses wanted to see them correlate room access with downtime events, like routers going down, UPS/power issues, etc. That never happened AFAIK, but it was used mostly to see when the employees were working and how hard -- moving in and out of rooms a lot meant motion == handling tickets. Sitting in the NOC == doing nothing, or so they thought.Correlating entry to valid access tickets and/or loading dock removal tickets was another idea but never materialized.

Yes. We do it.Useful for running reports and seeing who doesn’t come into the office (ask me how I know) - and no this is not the primary use-case.You can use this data for correlation searches. Employee A badged into a building in the US, however, they are accessing the network from Asia.Maybe something is not right?

The whole point of a SIEM is to feed it anything. And I mean anything. Create your own logs and feed it, whatever makes sense for your work. Someone entered office - log it Someone logged physically on a server - log it Etc

We actually just went through a "security log reconciliation process", if you will. I would say it's more than network infrastructure, but still doesn't include physical event logs.We're including endpoint security logs, AWS, our SaaS apps (we're 80% cloud based), on-prem DC, Azure AD, impossible travel, unapproved countries, etc. Likely a lot I am forgetting.However, we do reconcile physical security on a quarterly basis. Our only "restricted" room is our data closet. I actually loop the physical review in with the quarterly RBAC review. I don't actually look for unauthorized access, I just confirm that those who do have access still have it for valid reasons. Other than internal colleagues I'm basically just ensuring that third-party contractors who may have access to the data closet have their access timely removed when no longer required, and that if it is required, that we have a ticket or case documented with the dates and reasons for having said access.

What is the best way to secure a scan engine ?? I need tips..

Install on Linux and minimize the install. Patch, patch, patch. It sounds like you have your console hosted externally; use engine->console communication (instead of the opposite) so that you don’t need to make the scan engine accessible for externally-originated connections.Monitor the engine with your SIEM; while it will generate tons of traffic its behavior at the system level will very extremely boring and simple, so identifying variations should be relatively simple. Also, inbound connections should come from only a few places over even fewer protocols.DM me if you’d like to discuss this further, I’m happy to help.

Our horizontal access is controlled by campus firewall segmentation where we separate production from enterprise vrfs. If we are talking about campus zones / production / datacenter zones, then we simply create a firewall rule to allow our scanning engines access to any destination IP over any Interface over any port, and we put the fw rule above all other fw rules (logically). This allows our scanning device unlimited horizontal access. Scanning in our dmz and cloud environments are similar but we don’t use vrfs and simply allow the scanner IPs to access the dmz zones (subnets) via fw rule and nat if needed.Since you don’t say anything about your environment, there is no suggestion to give.

Great question. Keep in mind most folks will create an IPS exemption for their scanner as it will trigger most alerts since that's it's job. That generally leaves a box that has access to everything without any controls.Few things you can do:Deploy multiple scanning engines in each security layer/zoning. No one engine has full reign over the entire org.Enable certain security monitoring such as C2 detection/tunneling. The engine should scan for vulns but would never initiate cobalt strike c2 for example.Extremely limit outbound Internet connectivity for the scanner. Updates only.Run your EDR/EPP on the base OS assuming it's not an appliance ( you may have to tune the profile so the outbound scans don't trigger behavior triggers)

Are you sure they actually would have sent a verification code to those numbers, instead of simply using it as a generic verification service a la https://id.me?

It'd be much easier for a hacker to get your current number, hijack it with the carrier and then just have the code sent to it. To get that number they just have to send a text that you'll reply to, even if it's stop. That then confirms the number is active and from there they can figure out the rest pretty easy.

Those numbers are being associated to you via Public Record most likely via Lexis Nexis. The chances of you being compromised due to those listed numbers is slim to none unless they have your acct #, SSN and other validating information and access to one of your old phone numbers which is extremely unlikely. I’ll be surprised if BoA does anything for you when you call back as it’s not data stored in their system and is being pulled from Public Record.

Dude, take the downvotes in the previous post you aren’t getting it. This is a common practice many many financial institutions use. A hacker isn’t going to compromise the date base to add new numbers. The database is comprised of data from telecom providers. So, a bad actor would need to identify theft you, then open a cell phone number in your name and eventually wait for that come into the records. If they identify theft’s you already they would just open up a line of credit in your name and move on, not takeover an existing account.

Having worked with BofA in the past, this isn't surprising.I got massively downvoted in the comments section of the last post for expressing concerns that this is a security risk. Or couldn’t they register a phone number in someone’s name and then use that number to gain access to their financial accounts?It could be. But what they're doing is almost certainly just enrichment. 1: First firewall filter rule - which is left disabled - is an emergency network cutoff of the LAN from the outside world. No traffic allowed in or out. This allows internal systems to remain operative, but is designed to isolate the network from a large-scale cyberattack (nation-state type) with a single click.2: Last firewall rule - which is always on - blocks all traffic in or out that has not been previously allowed by other filter rules.3: All filter rules in between those two are based on that network's specific needs, and only traffic necessary to conduct business is allowed in or out.4: Traffic to and from Russia, China, North Korea, and Iran is specifically blocked (assuming the company doesn't do business in those countries).
Last rule is your blanket implicit deny. Plan in periodic reviews of your ACLs; cadence based on what they are protecting.
